title: An important next step on our AI journey

last_post.content:
Google used to take pride in minimizing time we spent there, guiding us to relevant pages as quickly as possible. Over time, they tried to answer everything themselves: longer snippets, inline FAQs, search results full of knowledge panels.

Today's Bard announcement feels like their natural evolution: extracting all value out of the internet for themselves, burying pages at the bottom of each GPT-generated essay like footnotes. https://blog.google/technology/ai/bard-google-ai-search-updates/

title: We come to bury ChatGPT, not to praise it.

last_post.content:
“Instead of reactionary solutionism, let us ask where the technologies are that people really need. Let us reclaim the idea of socially useful production, of technological developments that start from community needs. The post-Covid 'new normal' has turned out to involve both the normalisation of neural networks and a rise in necropolitics”

Some fire from @danmcquillan https://www.danmcquillan.org/chatgpt.html

title: StreetPass for Mastodon

last_post.content:
StreetPass is a cool new browser extension that uses Mastodon's verification system in a clever way.

Mastodon users verify themselves by adding a custom link to their personal site. StreetPass lets you know when you've found one of these links, and adds them to your list. As you browse the web, StreetPass will build a list of Mastodon users that belong to the websites you visit.

I spoke with the creater @tvler about the project, 🧵 below.

Visit https://streetpass.social/ to try it yourself!

title: Mastodon Continues to Lose Users

last_post.content:
More strange Mastodon reporting. This time from @thurrott, who claims "I’ve been using Mastodon since December, but the interaction there is almost non-existent compared to Twitter."

Dude, you follow 22 people. Try following more people. The "non-existent" interaction is *up to you*.

I've found WAY MORE interactions and engagement here than I ever had on Twitter. Plus fewer death threats.

https://www.thurrott.com/cloud/social/279094/mastodon-continues-to-lose-users

title: Creating a Large Language Model of a Philosopher

last_post.content:
"Creating a Large Language Model of a Philosopher"
Eric Schwitzgebel, David Schwitzgebel, Anna Strasser
https://arxiv.org/abs/2302.01339

"To explore the Dennett model, we asked the real Dennett ten philosophical questions and then posed the same questions to the language model, collecting four responses for each question without cherry-picking."

title: https://pruvisto.org/debirdify

last_post.content:
Are you trying to find your contacts from Twitter on Mastodon?

There are online tools which can help with this, however Twitter is apparently going to shut them down by Thursday 9th February.

If you want to use these, now would seem to be your last chance:

🐦 Debirdify
https://pruvisto.org/debirdify

🔍 Fedifinder
https://fedifinder.glitch.me

A third tool, Movetodon, has already been shut down by Twitter.

title: Cosmic Threads: A Solar System Quilt from 1876

last_post.content:
In the autumn of 1883, a paper in the nation's capital reported that "an Iowa woman has spent 7 years embroidering the solar system on a quilt."

Ellen Harding Baker used her stunning quilt to teach astronomy in an era when women could not attend college:
https://www.themarginalian.org/2018/12/06/ellen-harding-baker-solar-system-quilt/

title: magazine.amstat.org/blog/2018/...

last_post.content:
A brief #introduction: I'm a data scientist w/ a math+stats background. I've been with the Wikimedia Foundation (the non-profit behind Wikipedia) for 7y+ and I've been managing since 2021

You may have read my guide on hiring: https://magazine.amstat.org/blog/2018/09/01/hiring-a-data-scientist/

I’ve written about my journey as an individual contributor (back in 2017) on my blog: https://mpopov.com/blog/2017/09/21/the-journey-so-far/

I've authored a few R packages, most notably WikidataQueryServiceR

You can learn about my team and what we do at https://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Product_Analytics

title: Editing a Woman's Voice

last_post.content:
via Susanna Berkouwer
Another wild finding:
Male & female economists write with similar levels of uncertainty, but the writing of those assigned biased editors becomes more uncertain during review

Paper: https://arxiv.org/abs/2212.02581

title: https://lnkd.in/gwp7Aq9m

last_post.content:
📢 In a recent report, Microsoft Digital Threat Analysis Center (DTAC) attributes a recent influence operation targeting French satirical magazine Charlie Hebdo to an Iranian nation-state actor, NEPTUNIUM.

💧 In January, a hacker group known as "Holy Souls" claimed to have obtained the personal information of over 200,000 Charlie Hebdo customers. They released a sample of the data, which included full names, telephone numbers, and email and home addresses, putting subscribers at risk of targeting by extremist organizations.

🛡️ To help against these influence operations, DTAC also released their Influence Attribution Framework. This tool helps organizations understand, attribute, and mitigate the impact of these operations. For more information on how the framework works, I've put together a simple infographic that summarizes its key components. 👇 #microsoft #threatintelligence #influence #infosec #cybersecurity #microsoftsecurity

📰 Report: https://lnkd.in/gwp7Aq9m

⚙ Framework: https://lnkd.in/gVuv6D8S

title: Mastodon Embedding Tools - Patrick Curry (patrickcurry.com)

last_post.content: Want to embed a stream of your Mastodon posts on a website? Want to turn a thread or a bunch of comments into an article? I made some templates for y'all! https://patrickcurry.com/socials/mastodon/tools/

Open research data:

Survey of 14 research articles published in Psychological Science finds:

“(a) provision of cleaned data without raw data, (b) provision of raw data without cleaned data, and (c) no description of, or code for, the data-cleaning process.”

Open access: https://doi.org/10.1177/09567976221140828

Some Mastodonian authors: @cruwell, @deboraha, @maltoesermalte, @sandrajgeiger, @jmoneger, @sTeamTraen

last_post.content:
Gold found in my RSS feeds —

I just love the type of detailed craftsmanship and care @andy demonstrates here as he explains how he manages typographical flow with the use of a lobotomised owl and some CSS street smarts.

```
.stack > * + * {
margin-block-start: 1.5rem;
}
```

title: SandLab/element.js at a9eb111917b35553758b42d28978f68f8a5e6894 · TodePond/SandLab

last_post.content:
@akkartik Thanks! the sand's behaviour is defined in 129-154 here: https://github.com/TodePond/SandLab/blob/a9eb111917b35553758b42d28978f68f8a5e6894/source/element.js#L128

If the sand can 'move' down, it moves down.

Otherwise, if it's bigger than the minimum size, it tries to split into 2 cells (above and below), and the above cell tries to move sideways.

Otherwise, it tries to merge with a nearby sand cell.

So, yes! the fine cells merge back bigger when they can't move.

title: GitHub - samim23/polymath: Convert any music library into a music production sample-library with ML

last_post.content:
Wow! @jesse just hipped me to this amazing bit of #demix/#remix #AI #ML #music #python tech called Polymath.

"The tool automatically separates songs into stems (beats, bass, etc.), quantizes them to the same tempo and beat-grid (e.g. 120bpm) and analyzes musical structure, key (e.g C4, E3, etc.) and other infos (timbre, loudness, etc.). The result is a searchable sample library that streamlines the workflow for music producers, DJs, and ML audio developers."

https://github.com/samim23/polymath

title: Interface-Design, UX und die Forschung

last_post.content:
"Wie oft haben Sie ein digitales Forschungsangebot in Ihrem Browser oder gar auf Ihrem Smartphone geöffnet und gedacht: Mensch, das ist mal ein ansprechendes Design! Und so einfach! Nie? Selten?"

Warum es kompliziert ist mit Interface-Design, UX und der Forschung erklärt Jonas Müller-Laackman im neuen de.hypo-Blog ➡ DH3 👇

https://dh3.hypotheses.org/426

#DigitalHumanities #ux

title: Inside a Florida liberal arts college DeSantis wants to take over

last_post.content:
An article about what's going on at the New College of Florida cites the following data: "a majority of US professors identify as far left or liberal— 60% in 2017, up from 41% in 1990"

Meanwhile there's abundant data re: the rise of the academic precariat (adjuncts & other short-term-contracted jobs, e.g. my own) — roughly contemporaneous with the above. Professors who have to constantly worry about having an income & healthcare. Just an observation..

link: https://www.latimes.com/world-nation/story/2023-02-05/florida-liberal-arts-college-gov-ron-desantis-wants-to-take-over

#politics

title: Our Digital History Is at Risk - Internet Archive Blogs

last_post.content:
"Our Digital History Is at Risk" by me in Time Magazine

Free societies need access to history, unaltered by changing corporate or political interests.

This is the role that libraries have played and need to keep playing.

http://blog.archive.org/2023/02/07/our-digital-history-is-at-risk/

title: dplyr 1.1.0: `pick()`, `reframe()`, and `arrange()`

last_post.content:
The final post for dplyr 1.1.0 is out! #rstats 🎉

Today, we'll look at two new verbs:
- `pick()` for column selection
- `reframe()` as a way to "do anything" to each group

We'll also look at performance and reproducibility improvements to `arrange()`!

https://www.tidyverse.org/blog/2023/02/dplyr-1-1-0-pick-reframe-arrange/

title: Developing a globally fair pricing model for Open Access academic publishing | Plan S

last_post.content:
Plum job: "#cOAlition_S wishes to commission a study…to identify ways in which readers and producers of scholarly publications (or their proxies, namely research #funders and #universities) could financially contribute to supporting the academic publishing services valued by their research communities as a function of their means in a manner that is globally equitable and sustainable."
https://www.coalition-s.org/developing-a-globally-fair-pricing-model-for-open-access-academic-publishing/

If you want to undertake the study, apply before March 13.

#jobs #OpenAccess

last_post.content:
Join the 2nd Explainable AI for CV (XAI4CV) workshop at #CVPR2023!
https://xai4cv.github.io/workshop_cvpr23

👥 The workshop will take place on June 19th in Vancouver, Canada. More to follow on in-person/hybrid setup

🎤 We have a fantastic line-up of speakers: @qveraliao, Mohit Bansal, Marina M.-C. Höhne (née Vidovic), @arvind, Alice Xiang, and @davidbau

📄 Submit papers and demos by March 14th (proceedings track) and May 19th (non-proceedings track)

title: Nintendo Will Pay Its Workers 10% More

last_post.content:
Nintendo’s CEO recently said “If we reduce the number of employees for better short-term financial results, employee morale will decrease” and is instead doing the opposite by raising pay to address inflation.

Some leaders are built different.

https://www.gamespot.com/articles/nintendo-will-pay-its-workers-10-more/1100-6511268/

title: Very slow performance with some markdown options · Issue #2730 · jgm/pandoc

last_post.content: @allafarce @delong @timoreilly Threw in a credit card and now waiting for it to generate an index against ~7mb of markdown-formatted newsletter episodes. Markdown because I hit a problem like this with Pandoc converting them to plain text: https://github.com/jgm/pandoc/issues/2730, almost as if With 557 Markdown Files, Dan's GPT AI System Was At Risk -- Until This Weekend Hack Fixed It.

title: Why Stephen Hawking is more afraid of capitalism than robots

last_post.content:
@ramin_hal9001 @pluralistic This quote from Stephen Hawking is relevant in this context:

"Everyone can enjoy a life of luxurious leisure if the machine-produced wealth is shared, or most people can end up miserably poor if the machine-owners successfully lobby against wealth redistribution. So far, the trend seems to be toward the second option, with technology driving ever-increasing inequality."

https://www.vox.com/2016/2/27/11119804/stephen-hawking-robots

title: What I Think About LeBron Breaking My NBA Scoring Record

last_post.content: https://kareem.substack.com/p/what-i-think-about-lebron-breaking This is so completely not my world that it's not funny - I vaguely recognize the name LeBron James and could barely even have said that of Kareem Abdul-Jabbar. That's on me - I'm exactly that cliched kind of professor. Even so, coming from a place of nearly complete ignorance about their sporting accomplishments, I'm still interested in good prose and thinking. And damn - Abdul-Jabbar can write.
